contentrichtext.text: {{coord|53.652|-1.831|display=title|region:GB_scale:20000}} '''Quarmby''' is a district of [[Huddersfield]], [[West Yorkshire]], [[England]]. It is situated 2 miles west of Huddersfield town centre between [[Oakes, Huddersfield|Oakes]], [[Paddock, Huddersfield|Paddock]] and [[Longwood, West Yorkshire|Longwood]]. The holders of the land in the name of Eddward 1042-66 were Gamel and Godwin, whereas the cultivator at the time of the ''[[Domesday Book]]'' was Ilbert de Lacy. The Lacy family in Normandy derived their name from the commune of Lassy, the Lacius or Latius estates in the county of Calvados. The village of Lassy today is near the town of [[Vire]] in [[France]]. The name, originally Cornbei, is said to have been given by de Lacy. [[Category:Kirklees]] [[Category:Geography of Huddersfield]] {{WestYorkshire-geo-stub}}
